title.narrative: Food Security through Agribusiness in South Sudan (SSADP II)

description.narrative:
SSADP II aims at improving the food security, income and employment of 10,000 farmer households in Yambio, Torit and Bor counties through:
- Improving inclusive agribusiness market functioning - Enhancing sustainable production and productivity - Improving the performance of Cooperatives and Agri-MSMEs and creating new jobs - Making farmers and agri-entrepreneurs more resilient to shocks and hazards (both natural and man-made)
In this, the project strives to increase farmers and agribusiness Micro Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs), Cooperatives, Village Saving and Loan Associations (VSLA), youth and women entrepreneurs access to organization, technology, markets and finance through a Making Markets Work for the Poor (M4P) approach.

South Sudan is endowed with natural resources and more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese are engaged in agriculture. However, the majority are subsistence producers due to lack of quality inputs such as seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, farm tools along with challenges related to agricultural equipment, storage facilities and capital access. As a whole, there is also limited knowledge of improved farming techniques, water harvesting, irrigation methods and methods for reducing post-harvest losses. On top of these, recurring conflict and natural disasters create a feeling of uncertainty amongst farmers who might otherwise be interested to invest in a commercial farm both at small and at large scale. We believe the full potential of farmers can be unlocked with appropriate technical support.
The South Sudan Agribusiness Development Project II (SSADP II) is a five-year project that runs from late 2018 to July 2023 funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN) in South Sudan. The project is implemented by a consortium of NGOs including Cordaid, SPARK and Agriterra. Cordaid is the lead agency. The consortium works closely with the concerned ministries of the Government of South Sudan and key stakeholders in the country including local and international NGOs, UN Agencies, and private sector.

The main project targets include:
- 10.000 individual farmers - 350 Farmer Economic and Market Associations (FEMA/FFS) - 30 Local Seed Producers - 230 Cooperatives - 120 Village Saving and Loan Associations - 65 Business Development Advisers - 750 Agribusiness MSMEs - 1000 Youth and Women Entrepreneurs

Sustainable Livelihoods Corporate Indicators
Number of jobs created

description.narrative: Number of new jobs created by MSMEs, comparing before and after Cordaid's intervention (from baseline to Endline), counting only new jobs (not net jobs)

title.narrative: Number of unemployed youth successfully supported into (self)employment

description.narrative: Number of youth who have secured employment, comparing from before the intervention to after (baseline to Endline). NB Both waged employment and self-employment (i.e. are employed by someone else or have started their own business)

title.narrative: Number of people supported to improve and/or develop their entrepreneurship prospects

description.narrative: Number of people (within the project's target beneficiary group) supported by Cordaid interventions designed to assist them to develop / improve their entrepreneurship (possibilities)

title.narrative: Number of farmers applying good agricultural practices

description.narrative: Number of farmers that apply Good Agricultural Practices (GAP). GAP activities encompass different components of agricultural practice: dealing with agricultural inputs, handling fertilizers and pesticides use, harvesting practices and personal and product safety and hygiene (when applicable according to EU import regulations)

title.narrative: Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Number of farmers that have improved access to non-financial services

description.narrative: Number of farmers with improved access to non-financial services (Examples - number with increased access to markets e.g. new market linkages, number with increased access to inputs increase is measured from baseline to Endline)

title.narrative: Number of households with more diversified livelihoods (income generation)

description.narrative: Number of households that have been able to diversify their primary livelihood through Cordaid interventions on this field. Diversification here means the process by which rural families construct a diverse portfolio of activities and social support capabilities in order to survive and to improve their standards of living.

title.narrative: Number of (M)SMEs that have improved access to non-financial services

description.narrative: Number of MSMEs with improved access to non-financial services (Examples - number with increased access to markets e.g. new market linkages, number with increased access to inputs increase is measured from baseline to Endline)

title.narrative: Number of (M)SMEs that has increased annual revenue

description.narrative: Number of (M)SMEs with an increase in revenue, comparing before and after Cordaid's intervention (from baseline to endline). Score based on SCOPE Insight assessment can be 0.0 to 5.7.

title.narrative: Number of enterprises with improved access to finance

description.narrative: Number of enterprises (farmer enterprises or MSMEs) who have access to finance, comparing before and after our intervention (from baseline to Endline). NB A farmer group = 1 enterprise not 25 farmers. An individual farmer could be 1 enterprise

title.narrative: Number of SMEs reached

description.narrative: Number of SMEs tht have been reached directly or indirectly through the programme's activities.

title.narrative: Number of value chains that have become more inclusive for farmers and/or (m)SMEs

description.narrative: Number of formal (agricultural) value chains that have opened up for farmers ( or farmer's producer organizations) and/or (m)SMEs by giving them opportunities of (new) value-adding functions such as bulking, transporting, grading, processing and marketing

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SU)

description.narrative: Number of people who have benefitted (directly or indirectly) through a Cordaid Sustainable Livelihoods Intervention

title.narrative: Humanitarian Aid Corporate Indicators
Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Thematic Indicators
Number of SMEs that were able to access financing

description.narrative: Number of SMEs that accesses financing

title.narrative: Value of finance accessed by SMEs (EUR)

description.narrative: Value of financing accesses by SMEs

title.narrative: Number of CSOs/NGOs able to facilitate a community managed resilience/DRR process

description.narrative: Including 5 key steps

title.narrative: Number of SMES that have increased access to markets

description.narrative: Number SMEs with new customers

title.narrative: Number of Resilience Action Plans developed at community/local level

description.narrative: Number of communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and developed joint action plans to enhance resilience at the community/local level

title.narrative: Number of communities implementing Resilience measures

description.narrative: Number of targeted communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and (raise funds for and) carry out their action plans by implementing resilience interventions at the community/ local level

title.narrative: % of increase in annual revenue by SMEs
Number of direct beneficiaries enhanced their resilience through community level resilience activities
Number of Participatory Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRAs) done at community/local level
Number of DRR/Resilience committees established and functioning at local level
Number of communities engaged in participatory disaster risk analysis and joint resilience action planning, at local level
Number of communities reached

Number of people actively participating in VSLAs/savings groups

Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
